ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was also an hour-long "boot camp" in-person lab each week for those who signed up.
also live seminar/lecture
This was a virtual lab, however and optional in person lab was offered that I did attend prior to Yale going into code orange, completing the majority of our labs in person.
An in-person lab session was optional
Several in-person labs after the virtual lectures
In person lab section
there was also an optional in-person lab component

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course not only taught important technical skills in the in-person portion, but in the online portion, there was also a great deal of focus on theory, which I actually found was an important supplement to the biochemistry lecture that I was taking. By learning about specific experiments and their effects on the field of biochemistry, I left the course with a much greater understanding of foundational topics in biochemistry that had been covered in the lecture portion of the course.
Pipetting. A lot of pipetting. Also most of basic biochemistry laboratory skills.

As a whole, this class helped me understand how to formulate an experiment, start to beginning, from PCR amplification, to gel analysis, to various methods of protein purification, to understanding the effects mutations have on proteins, to the enzymatic kinetics of these effects. This class actually helped my formulate my grant proposal for my research seminar in MCDB. I knew almost exactly what to do in order to set up and carry out my experiment, perhaps only having to change certain reagents based on my own protein of interest, which was ACE2 receptor, instead of Staph nuclease, which we used in our lab.
Learned many techniques used in biochemistry research, also learned to write a good paper/lab report

I gained an understanding of common biochemistry laboratory techniques such as PCR, gel electrophoresis, bacterial transformation, DNA isolation, and protein purification. The in-person component allowed me to put some of the theory we learned about in the virtual lectures in practice. I learned how to write a comprehensive lab report. I also learned about conducting multi-step research experiments with controls.
I learned how to apply biochem lab te que a to complete a project on protein purification and exploration. A variety of techniques were used, giving a broad introduction to biological lab techniques!
I learned a lot about common biochemistry techniques.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: organized, flexible, amazing level of knowledge, really fun lab, great professors
Weaknesses: Very long class once a week, difficult over zoom to focus, lectures not super clear, some of the assignments are not in good english and thus hard to understand
Course was amazing, especially considering the circumstances. Dr. Pawashe is the best.

Strengths: good synthesis of all labs into the final project, which helped me understand how many experiments are needed to come together and accomplish a project

Weaknesses: lab sections were quite long towards the end of the semester, but this probably wouldn't have been an issue if the classes had been in person as normal

Strengths: I gained a deep understanding of the theory behind common biochemical techniques thanks to the extensive "lecture" component. The quizzes were fair and motivated me to stay engaged. The virtual Labster labs were fun to do. Although the in-person wet-lab component was very limited due to the pandemic restrictions, the opportunity to actually perform some experiments and practice the techniques we learned about made a huge difference. My TA, Kevin, was very helpful and willing to answer all my questions during the wet-lab. Lastly, the structure of the course as a semester-long project definitely helped me to see how all the different techniques we learned were relevant.

Weaknesses: it was very difficult to stay engaged during the virtual labs, especially when the virtual component occupied the full 4 hours. The final lab report was very time consuming. Due to the pandemic restrictions, we used data from last year for the lab report, and so the disconnect between what we actually did in the lab and what we were writing about made writing the report feel a little disingenuous.
I think its best transitioned to online learned through the use on Labster simulations
I really loved the virtual labs, I thought they were very engaging and they made learning really interesting.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated the Zoom breaks, since being on Zoom for multiple hours at a time can be draining. These breaks also gave us time to connect with the professors on a more personal level if we wanted to, which was really important in a semester during which it was at times hard to connect with people.

This course adapted very well to learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, incorporating a very well balanced class between discussion and lecture, and then actually doing the experiments for those who chose to.
Small breakout rooms to discuss questions and work on activities were very helpful, allowed me to get to know and interact with other students and also helped my understanding of concepts

Strengths: the in-person lab component went well in my opinion. I felt completely safe the whole time, and I was still able to gain valuable laboratory experience. The breakout rooms, in-class activities, and discussions during the virtual labs helped to break-up the long 4 hours.

Weaknesses: 4 hours on Zoom was too much at one time. Even with the breakout rooms and in-class activities, I still had a hard time staying engaged.

I would use Labster more and maybe go over what the simulations showed in person. Also maybe the zooms could show someone demonstrating techniques in real time, though I also recognize that might be technologically difficult.

I really loved the meditation at the start of every class, and the fact that we had a scheduled break in the middle of each class. Overall, I felt this course was structured really well and it really facilitated learning during the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Many people only take the biochemistry lecture, but I think that taking the lab portion allowed for a much deeper understanding of important foundational biochemistry concepts.
Take it! Professor Pawashe is worth it

I would highly recommend this course to any student looking to gain a better understanding of how research is carried out, and I would go so far as to say that Biochem Lab offers a better understanding of Biochemistry than the actual material heavy course.
Yes, but preferably in a non-virtual format!
Yes, good lab for pre-meds. Not too much work and the biology part of it is not hard. You get to take a deep dive into foundational laboratory techniques.
